Step 6 – Hazard identification for physical security and egress during live cutover (top three)

1) Policy and path conflicts delay or deny releases
Guide words: Late, Conflict, Unavailable, Misroute, Desync, Reverse.
Because fire events may traverse application programming interfaces across segmented networks during migration, security lockdown rules, firewall blocks, cloud identity checks, or time synchronization drift can delay or nullify release commands; therefore the less than one hundred millisecond envelope is breached and relock heartbeats may fire. This also suppresses elevator recall handoff or leaves turnstiles armed. Likelihood 4, Impact 5, Risk Score 20. This pattern has occurred in analogous cutovers, source verification required. What to verify: measure command arrival at controller, relay actuation, and door strike movement.

2) Door group mapping drift and interlock sequence errors
Guide words: Wrong, Part Of, Before, After, Bypass, Conflict.
Because zone-to-door group mapping can diverge during database moves, and mantrap or turnstile bypass signals may not precede unlocks, one leaf unlocks while the opposite stays secured or barriers stay up; therefore occupants are trapped or flow stalls at chokepoints. Elevator lobby readers can also remain authoritative during recall due to priority inversions. Likelihood 3, Impact 5, Risk Score 15. What to verify: crosswalks of fire zones to door groups, scripted interlock timing with less than one hundred millisecond stamps, and forced-fault tests for sequence ordering.

3) Compromised fail‑safe due to power and relay supervision gaps
Guide words: Unavailable, Degraded, Stuck, Bypass, Overload, Latent.
Because locks powered only by power over ethernet or nonlisted supplies lack local fire trip and supervised release, midspan failures or remote reboots can leave doors locked or cause relock during the alarm; therefore egress becomes nondeterministic and audit trails may be blind. Unsurvised fire relays can fail silently closed. Likelihood 3, Impact 5, Risk Score 15. What to verify: power source independence, supervised release circuit health, and live cut power-down with measured door safe-state within one hundred milliseconds.

What gaps do you see, especially around identity dependencies and destination dispatch nuances?

Step 6 – Physical security and egress control integration hazards during live cutover (identity and destination dispatch focus)

The prior three hazards are strong, yet they understate identity service coupling and elevator destination dispatch priority conflicts; these two families routinely violate the less than one hundred millisecond envelope during migrations, therefore they create unacceptable lock‑in risk.

1) Identity‑coupled overrides block or delay egress
Guide words: Unavailable, Late, Desync, Wrong, Bypass. Components: access control controller, identity provider, time source.
Because some controllers evaluate alarm overrides through role or token checks and time validation, any identity outage or clock drift stalls unlocks; therefore relock heartbeats may fire and turnstiles stay armed. L 4, I 5, Risk Score 20. Verify by isolating identity services and time sources during alarm and proving local supervised fire relay unlocks within less than one hundred milliseconds at the lock head.

2) Destination dispatch recall conflicts with security gating
Guide words: Conflict, Before, After, Reverse, Other Than. Components: elevator controller, dispatch engine, lobby barriers.
Because destination dispatch binds car calls to authenticated passengers and floor rights, recall and firefighter service can be blocked if security rules and lobby readers remain authoritative; therefore cars bypass safe floors and lobby doors or turnstiles remain closed. L 3, I 5, Risk Score 15. Verify by injecting recall under normal restrictions and confirming automatic bypass of readers, drop of barriers, and command‑to‑car motion latencies within budget.

3) Anti‑passback, tailgate, and lockdown macros persist during alarms
Guide words: Conflict, As Well As, Reverse, Stuck. Components: turnstiles, interlocks, door controllers.
Because enforcement engines may not suspend on alarm, exit lanes can deny travel or relock after first passage; therefore egress flow stalls at chokepoints. L 3, I 4, Risk Score 12. Verify by running alarm under active lockdown and anti‑passback and demonstrating uninterrupted free egress with no relock over sustained flow.

4) Reader communications bus overload or spoof holds secure
Guide words: Overload, Spoofed, Intermittent, Stuck, Bypass. Components: reader bus, controller firmware.
Because a storm or spoof can starve or crash software release paths, doors may fail to unlock or relock mid‑evacuation; therefore reliance on bus‑mediated commands violates determinism. L 3, I 4, Risk Score 12. Verify by disabling the bus or injecting load during alarm and proving the supervised hardwired fire relay with independent power unlocks within less than one hundred milliseconds.

The section strengthens coverage by exposing identity service coupling and elevator destination dispatch conflicts, both of which frequently break deterministic egress during migrations. While the first hazard assumes some controllers gate overrides through identity and time checks, several platforms hardwire fire precedence; however migrations often reintroduce software mediation, so the high rating remains defensible. Therefore require proof that a supervised, hardwired fire relay unlocks every relevant opening within less than one hundred milliseconds with identity and time services isolated.

The destination dispatch item presumes firefighter service should preempt security, yet integration layers can misorder priorities, especially when lobby barriers retain authority. Therefore mandate physical fire signals to elevator control and barrier drop circuits, automatic suspension of destination dispatch authentication on alarm, and timing tests that demonstrate reader bypass and car availability within the defined envelope.

The anti passback and lockdown concern is rated medium, but chokepoint accumulation can escalate consequences; therefore enforce a nonrevocable global suspend of these macros upon alarm assertion and verify no relock under sustained occupant flow.

The reader communications bus overload scenario matters only when unlock depends on the bus; however software mediated paths frequently exist as a secondary release, so the risk is valid. Therefore validate that bus loss, spoof, or storm cannot prevent or resecure doors during alarms and that the hardwired path with independent power remains authoritative.

Cross cutting verification is sound but should be made more explicit because latency budgets are tight. Therefore instrument at command egress, relay coil, lock power, and door position, and require tamper resistant logging of the three timestamps for every test and live event. Residual gap: evacuation routing decisions interacting with lobby gating should be fault injected, since misroutes can recreate lock in patterns even when doors are released.
